Cationic ruthenium(II)-CNC pincer complexes as phosphine-free catalysts for nitrile hydration to amides in aqueous medium Rahul Kumar Singh Methodology Investigation Data curation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Dibya Yadav Formal analysis Writing – original draft Amrendra K. Singh Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology Indore, Indore 453552, India Department of Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology Indore Indore 453552 India Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology Indore, Indore 453552, India ⁎ Corresponding author. We report the synthesis, characterization, and catalytic activity of a series of electron-rich, phosphine-free complexes featuring multiple N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands, namely [Ru(CNC i- Pr)(CNMe)I]PF6 (1a), [Ru(CNC i- Pr)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (1b), [Ru(CNCCy)(CNMe)I]PF6 (2a), [Ru(CNCCy)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (2b), [Ru(CNC t -Bu)(CNMe)I]PF6 (3a), and [Ru(CNC t -Bu)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (3b) (where CNC = 2,6-bis(alkylimidazol-2-ylidene)-pyridine and CN = 2-(3-alkylimidazol-2-ylidene)-pyridine). Spectroscopic characterization using multinuclear NMR and high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) confirms the composition of all complexes. The molecular structures of 1a and 2a were further confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The catalytic activity of these ruthenium(II) complexes in the hydration of nitriles under mild reaction conditions and in the aqueous medium have been explored, with complex 1a exhibiting superior reactivity among the studied complexes. Mechanistic investigations revealed a catalytic pathway initiated by a [Ru-OH] species, facilitated by the hemilability of a pyridine ligand. The versatility of these ruthenium(II) complexes as catalysts for nitrile hydration has been demonstrated through successful conversions of a diverse range of nitriles, containing electron-releasing or electron-withdrawing groups, and heterocyclic nitriles into the corresponding amides with high reactivity and good to excellent yields. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ruthenium-pincer Phosphine-free Nitrile hydration Green synthesis Data availability X-ray crystal structural data has been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, the deposition numbers 2263541-2 for complexes 1a and 2a, respectively. 1 Introduction Ru-NHC complexes (NHC = N-heterocyclic carbene) exhibit exceptional versatility in catalytic applications, providing efficient solutions for converting renewable resources and synthesizing valuable products [1–7]. These complexes have been successfully employed in diverse reactions, such as cross-coupling reactions, (de)hydrogenation, metathesis, and C-H activation [8–18]. Their ability to engage in different types of bond activations and transformations stems from the unique electronic and steric properties of NHC ligands and the tunable reactivity of ruthenium [19–24]. This versatility makes Ru-NHC complexes invaluable tools in synthetic chemistry, particularly as phosphine-free catalysts, enabling the efficient synthesis of complex molecules and facilitating the development of sustainable and environmentally friendly processes [25–29]. Traditional transition metal catalysts often rely on phosphine ligands to stabilize the metal center and modulate reactivity. However, the use of phosphine ligands can come with certain drawbacks, including toxicity, air and moisture sensitivity, and limited ligand tunability [30,31]. Ru-NHC complexes represent a highly attractive class of phosphine-free catalysts, offering outstanding stability, reactivity, and selectivity [32–35]. These catalysts have the potential to revolutionize various synthetic methodologies and promote more sustainable and environmentally friendly chemical processes. Amides hold immense importance in chemical and biological systems, finding widespread applications as synthetic intermediates in pharmaceuticals, materials science, polymer chemistry, and fine chemical production [36–39]. Various synthetic methods have been reported for the synthesis of amides, with the condensation of carboxylic acids and amines considered as the more convenient approach [38–42]. Among the numerous strategies explored, the hydration of nitriles has emerged as a convenient and sustainable approach due to its environmentally friendly nature and absence of toxic byproducts [37,41,43]. Traditional methods for nitrile hydration, however, have suffered from drawbacks such as harsh reaction conditions involving highly alkaline or acidic media, which are neither sustainable nor practical from an environmental standpoint [44–46]. Moreover, the overhydrolysis of amides into carboxylic acids or ammonium carboxylates limits the applicability of this method, particularly when additional sensitive functional groups are present [44,45]. Hence, the development of atom-efficient catalytic procedures that prevent overhydration has become a highly desirable objective in modern chemistry. Numerous transition metal-based catalysts have been reported for the hydration of nitriles, enabling the direct nucleophilic addition of a water molecule to a nitrile bond and facilitating amide formation [40,43,47–52]. Notably, ruthenium complexes have emerged as effective catalysts, offering the potential for improved selectivity and efficiency in the hydration of nitriles under mild reaction conditions [53–59]. Several ruthenium-based catalysts have been reported for hydration of nitriles in aqueous medium but with higher catalyst loading (2–5 mol%) and at higher temperature (80–100 ˚C) [47,54,60–66]. Cadierno and coworkers investigated the ruthenium catalyst for hydration of nitriles with low catalyst loading (1 mol%) in aqueous medium [57]. Recently, Otten [37] and Gupta [53] described ruthenium catalysed hydration of nitriles under mild reaction conditions with a pincer and tridentate ligand. Some selected active ruthenium catalysts for hydration of nitriles under mild reaction conditions are shown below (Fig. 1 ). Other transition metal catalysts have been also investigated for hydration of nitriles under mild reaction conditions viz. Rh [48,67], Ir [50], Os [68], Au [69], and Pt [70], metals with or without additives. Our group has been investigating the use of cationic Ru(II)-CNC (CNC = pyridine-dicarbene pincer ligands) complexes with smaller N-alkyl wingtips on NHC for hydrogenation/dehydrogenation and related catalysis [71–73]. More recently, we have reported the base-free synthesis of a simple Ru(III)-NHC complexes of the type [Ru(CN)(H2O)Cl3] (CN = a bidentate, pyridine-carbene ligand) and their use as a precursor to prepare new ruthenium complexes [74]. Herein, we report a library of electron-rich cationic Ru(II)-CNC pincer complexes [Ru(CNC i- Pr)(CNMe)I]PF6 (1a), [Ru(CNC i- Pr)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (1b), [Ru(CNCCy)(CNMe)I]PF6 (2a), [Ru(CNCCy)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (2b), [Ru(CNC t -Bu)(CNMe)I]PF6 (3a), and [Ru(CNC t -Bu)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (3b) with smaller and bulky N-wingtips based CNC pincer ligands. Ru(II)-NHC complexes were synthesized by a simple procedure through the reaction of a bidentate Ruthenium precursor with CNC pincer ligand under refluxed conditions. The catalytic reactivity was investigated for the hydration of nitriles under mild reaction conditions in an aqueous medium that afforded excellent yield. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of Ru(II)-CNC pincer complexes CNC pincer ligand precursors (CNC i -Pr·2HBr = 2,6-bis[3-(isopropyl)imidazolium]pyridine dibromide and CNCCy·2HBr = 2,6-bis[3-(cyclohexyl)imidazolium]pyridine dibromide) and CNC t -Bu·2HBr = 2,6-bis[3-(tert-butyl)imidazolium]pyridine dibromide) were prepared according to the reported procedure in the literature using 2,6-dibromopyridine and different alkyl-substituted imidazoles [75,76]. The reaction of ruthenium precursor [Ru(CNR')(H2O)Cl3] (R' = Me, i Pr), and pincer ligand precursors CNCR·2HBr (R = i-Pr, Cy, and t-Bu) in ethylene glycol under reflux condition, followed by ion exchange with the saturated solution of KPF6 afforded complexes [Ru(CNC i- Pr)(CNMe)I]PF6 (1a), [Ru(CNC i- Pr)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (1b), [Ru(CNCCy)(CNMe)I]PF6 (2a), [Ru(CNCCy)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (2b), [Ru(CNC t -Bu)(CNMe)I]PF6 (3a), and [Ru(CNC t -Bu)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (3b) (Scheme 1 ). The addition of excess sodium iodide was found necessary to avoid formation of products with different halides in the coordination sphere. All new complexes have been characterized by multinuclear NMR and HRMS techniques, and the solid-state structure of complexes 1a and 2a have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction technique. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra of complex 1a in dmso-d6 show two sets of signals for each of the protons expected indicating the existence of two species in solution. This could be due to the existence of cis/trans-isomers with respect to the two pyridine units, or due to a ligand substitution by a dmso-d6 molecule resulting in an equilibrium between two forms. Structurally similar complexes with terpyridine ligand have been reported to give cis/trans-isomers with respect to the two pyridine units by Rodríguez group [77]. However, since the solid-state structures of 1a, and 2a (vide infra) shows the species which have pyridine-pyridine trans to each other, the substitution of a labile ligand by a dmso-d6 molecule seems more feasible in this case. Two possibilities for substitution can be considered, either iodide dissociated from the metal centre or hemilabile pyridine of the bidentate ligand dissociated from the metal centre. If bidentate hemilabile pyridine was dissociated from the metal centre, then the ortho proton of the pyridine ligand would be expected to show a further upfield shifted signal, which is not the case here. Further, the iodide ligand trans to an NHC ligand is expected to be labile. Therefore, we are inclined to believe iodide substitution by a nucleophilic DMSO solvent molecule. To confirm this assumption, NMR spectra for these complexes have been recorded in less nucleophilic, non-coordinating solvent acetone-d6 which show only one species in the solution. Figs. 2 and 3 show the 1H NMR spectra of 1a in dmso-d6 and acetone-d6, respectively, confirming only one molecular species in the acetone-d6 solution. The formation of only trans-isomer could be explained as arising from the steric effects of N-alky substituents in the plane of CNC pincer ligand. Additionally, for the cis-isomer, the N-alkyl substituents of bidentate CN ligand will be closer to the N-alkyl substituents of CNC ligand while in trans-isomer they are away, making the pyridine-pyridine trans-isomer relatively less crowded. In 1H NMR spectra of complexes 1a and 1b, doublets for ortho protons of the pyridine ring of bidentate ligand are observed at 10.51 and 10.54 ppm, respectively, similar to the previously reported complex [Ru(CNC n-Bu)(CN n-Bu)Br]PF6 [29]. The isopropyl groups of pincer ligand give one multiplet at 3.54 – 3.46 (1a) and 3.48 – 3.40 ppm (1b) for methine proton and two doublets for the methyl groups at 1.34 (1a), 1.31 (1b), 0.91 (1a), and 0.89 ppm (1b). In complex 1a, a singlet for bidentate methyl proton at 2.72 ppm, while in complex 1b the isopropyl protons of bidentate CN ligand appear at 2.96 – 2.90 ppm for methine proton and a doublet for methyl proton at 0.82 ppm. In the 13C NMR spectrum, the carbene signals of complexes 1a and 1b appear at δ 193.87 and 194.07 ppm for CNC and 191.59 and 189.81 ppm for CNMe ligand, respectively, similar to previously reported ruthenium complex [29]. We have assigned the peaks for 13C NMR by comparing the spectra of set of complexes containing same CNC but different CN ligands (e.g., complexes 1a and 1b, having CNC i - Pr but different CNMe or CN i - Pr ligands, respectively). The signal showing significant change in chemical shift upon change in N-alkyl group of CN ligand has been assigned as the carbene signal of the CN ligand. 31P NMR spectrum shows peaks at δ, -144.24, and -144.23 ppm for PF6 − counterion, and their splitting as a septate due to coupling with six 19F nuclei. Complexes 1a and 1b in acetonitrile displayed the ESI+ HRMS signal at m/z 683.0699 and 711.0995, respectively, assigned to [M-PF6]+. The 1H NMR spectra of complexes 2a and 2b, show a doublet for ortho protons of the pyridine ring of bidentate ligand at 10.57 and 10.59 ppm, similar to the previously reported complex [Ru(CNC n-Bu)(CN n-Bu)Br]PF6 [29]. The aliphatic proton of cyclohexyl for methine proton appears as a multiplet at 3.11 – 3.05 ppm and 2.91 – 2.84 ppm, and other peaks for cyclohexyl appear at their expected position in the aliphatic region. The methyl protons of bidentate ligand in complex 2a appears at 2.71 ppm, while the isopropyl group of complex 2b appears as a multiplet at 3.04 – 3.02 ppm for methine proton and a doublet for methyl proton at 0.81 ppm. In the 13C NMR spectrum of 2a and 2b, the carbene carbon signals appear at 193.99 and 194.09 ppm for CNC and 191.91 and 190.04 ppm for CN ligand, similar to 1a and 1b and previously reported ruthenium complex [29]. 31P NMR spectrum shows peaks at -144.25 and -144.24 ppm for PF6 − counterion, and their splitting as a septate due to coupling with six 19F nuclei. HRMS of complexes 2a and 2b, in acetonitrile displayed the ESI+ signals at m/z 763.1314 and 791.1618, respectively, assigned to [M-PF6]+. In the 1H NMR spectrum of complexes 3a and 3b, a doublet appears at 10.14 and 10.21 ppm for ortho protons of the pyridine ring of bidentate ligand. A singlet appears at 1.16 and 1.15 ppm for the aliphatic protons of the t-butyl group in 3a and 3b, respectively. The methyl protons bidentate ligand of 3a resonates at 2.73 ppm, while isopropyl proton of 3b appears as a multiplet at 2.96 – 2.90 ppm for methine proton and a doublet at 0.82 ppm for methyl protons. The CNC carbene carbon signals in 13C NMR appear at 189.90 and 190.10 ppm for 3a and 3b, respectively, while the carbene signals for CN ligand appear at 192.32 and 190.52 ppm for 3a and 3b, respectively. 31P NMR spectrum shows peaks at -144.23 and -144.22 ppm for PF6 − counterion, and their splitting as a septate due to coupling with six 19F nuclei. The HRMS of complexes 3a and 3b in acetonitrile show ESI+ signal at m/z 711.0997 and 739.1301, respectively, assigned to [M-PF6]+. 2.2 Description of the crystal structures The molecular structures of complexes 1a and 2a have been confirmed by X-ray crystal diffraction analysis, and their structural parameters and final refinements for the complexes are given in Table S1. Complexes 1a and 2a crystallized in a monoclinic system with P21/c space group with a ruthenium metal center in distorted octahedral geometry. The structure of both the complexes 1a and 2a consists of two almost planar five-membered metallacycles of the CNC pincer ligand, one five-membered metallacycle of the CN ligand, and I− ion which occupies the sixth coordination position around the ruthenium atom (Fig. 4 ). The CNC ligand is tridentate chelating ligand occupies three meridional sites with C1-Ru1-C2 angle 155.28(10)° in 1a and 155.3(2)° in 2a, and their bite angles of C1-Ru1-N1 are 77.79(9)° in 1a and 77.9(2)° in 2a, while CN ligand is bidentate ligand occupies two sites at the ruthenium center, with bite angles of N2-Ru1-C3 are 77.48(10) in 1a and 77.5(2) in 2a, similar to our previously reported complexes [73]. In both complexes, the two pyridine units from CNC and CN ligands are trans to each other. Notably, the Ru-I bond trans to carbene with bond lengths 2.8149 Å in 1a and 2.8148 Å in 2a, are longer than a previously reported complex Ru-I, 2.7671 Å [78], indicating the labile nature of the iodide ligand due to greater trans effect of the carbene ligand. The bond lengths of Ru-N of the pyridine group (∼1.9 - 2.1 Å) [73] are similar to the previously reported metal complexes whereas Ru–C(NHC) bond lengths (∼1.9- 2.1 Å) [73] are also similar to analogous complexes [74]. 2.3 Catalytic application in hydration of nitriles All the synthesized cationic Ru(II) CNC pincer complexes were investigated for the catalytic application for the hydration of nitriles. Initially, we have taken benzonitrile as a model substrate with a catalytic amount of base and ruthenium catalyst in an aqueous medium. The conversion was monitored by GCMS to evaluate the catalytic reactivity of pincer complexes. Catalysis using 1 mmol of benzonitrile with 1 mol% catalyst 1a and catalytic amount of NaOH (20 mol%) at 60 ˚C for 6 h afforded maximum conversion (>99%, Table 1 , Entry 3). Using similar reaction conditions for catalysts 1b, 2a, 2b, 3a and 3b, we found good to moderate reactivity with 96%, 72%, 73%, 62%, and 61% conversions (Table 1, Entry 14-18). Further, decreasing the amount of NaOH with 10 and 15 mol% under similar reaction conditions shows lower catalytic reactivity with 77% and 89% conversions, respectively (Table 1, Entry 1-2). The catalytic activity was also investigated with different bases like KOH, NaHCO3, and Na2CO3. While NaHCO3, and Na2CO3 show considerably lower reactivity (27% and 40%, respectively) as compared to NaOH, KOH gave comparable activity with 95% conversion (Table 1, Entry 4-6). Under similar reaction conditions with a lower catalyst loading of 0.5 mol%, the catalyst reactivity decreased and shows almost half conversion 54% in 6 hours while increasing the reaction time to 12 hours affords only 76% conversion (Table 1, Entry 12-13). By decreasing the reaction time from 6 h to 2 h and 4 h, the conversion was also affected, and the reactivity was decreased to 53% and 77% conversions (Table 1, Entry 7-8). Further, investigation of the reactivity at lower temperatures from 30 ˚C, 40 ˚C, and 50 ˚C, the reactivity again decreases with 17%, 38%, and 76% conversions, respectively (Table 1, Entry 9-11). Additionally, the reactivity was also investigated with optimized reaction conditions with no catalyst loading showing only 20% conversion (Table 1, Entry 20), and without base, with only 17% conversion (Table 1, Entry 19). Furthermore, a control experiment under optimized reaction conditions without base and catalyst shows no reaction (Table 1, Entry 21). 2.4 Substrate scope for hydration of nitriles Hydration of nitriles including several aromatic substituted nitriles, heterocyclic nitriles and aliphatic nitriles were explored under the optimized reaction conditions. It was observed that the complex 1a typically produces high yields and works well as a pre-catalyst for a variety of substrates. Substrates containing electron-donating or electron-withdrawing substituents in the aryl group of nitriles reacted smoothly under optimized reaction conditions to produce the amides product with high isolated yields (Table 2 ). All the amides product were isolated by crystallisation, purified by column chromatography and characterized by NMR spectrocopy. Hydration of benzonitrile gave excellent yield 93% with maximum selectivity for benzamide (5a), which is also used as a model substrate. Similarly, 3-Methylbenzonitrile, 4-Methylbenzonitrile, 3-Methoxybenzonitrile and 4-Methoxybenzonitrile gave good yields of amides as the sole product with 76%, 82%, 73% and 87%, respectively (5b–5e). 2-Aminobenzonitrile, 3-Aminobenzonitrile and 4-Aminobenzonitrile have also afforded good yields as 71% 46% and 81%, respectively (5f–5h). However, 4-Cyanobenzaldehyde shows poor reactivity even after increasing temperature and time of the reaction gave only 48% yield (5j). Similarly, Methyl 4-Cyanobenzoate shows poor catalytic reactivity and gave a lower isolated yield of 53% (5k). However, 4-Hydroxybenzonitrile (4i) and 4-Cyanobenzoic acid (4l) do not show any reactivity under the optimized reaction conditions. Further, 2-Nitrobenzonitrile, 3-Nitrobenzonitrile and 4-Nitrobenzonitrile gave good isolated yields of 48%, 77% and 74%, respectively (5m–5o) under similar reaction conditions. Halogen-substituted nitriles i.e., 2-Chlorobenzonitrile and 2-Bromobenzonitrile show good reactivity and afforded good isolated yields 65% (5p) and 62% (5q), while 4-Chlorobenzonitrile, 4-Bromobenzonitrile and 4-Iodobenzonitrile also afforded better yields of 81% 75% and 77%, respectively (5r–5t). 2-Naphthonitrile also reacts well and gave excellent yield of 89% under similar reaction conditions (5u). However, Cinnamonitrile afforded Cinnamamide product with lower yield (57%) as compared to other aryl amide products (5v). Additionally, we explored the reactivity of heterocyclic nitriles i.e., 3-Cyanopyridine, 4-Cyanopyridine and 2-Thiophenecarbonitrile under similar reaction conditions which afforded good yields viz; 62%, 67% and 85%, respectively (5w–5y). Product of 3-Cyanopyridine is nicotinamide (5w), which is a biologically active compound, has anti-inflammatory properties and is helpful for those with inflammatory skin problems [79,80]. Aliphatic nitrile, butyronitrile gave a poor yield of only 34% (5z). 2.5 Mechanism for hydration of nitrile The hydration of nitriles catalyzed by transition metal complexes has been shown to follow slightly different mechanisms and involve different types of intermediates depending on the catalyst precursor [37,40,55]. Recently, ruthenium complexes based on amide-phosphine pincer ligands were shown to catalyse the base-free hydration of nitriles via Ru–H···H–OH dihydrogen bonding interaction in the catalytic cycle [53]. To get some insight into the reaction mechanism and reactive intermediates, we have analysed our catalytic samples using mass spectrometry. ESI-MS analysis of the catalytic mixture reveals the formation of a Ru-OH species, A in the first hour of the reaction (see SI, Fig. S28). Otten and coworkers have reported the hydration of nitriles catalyzed by ruthenium pincer complexes through a metal ligand cooperative effect in the catalytic cycle and appearance of a Ru-OH species during the catalysis [37]. Further, the nitrile bound species B is also detected in the mass spectrum of the catalytic mixture after three hours (see SI, Fig. S29). A plausible mechanism starting from the most efficient precatalyst 1a and involving an active intermediate Ru-hydroxy complex A is proposed in Fig. 5 . The catalytic reaction of hydration of nitriles involves a preliminary step that begins with the generation of ruthenium hydroxy species A by the reaction of complex 1a with the base (NaOH or KOH) or base + water (Na2CO3 or NaHCO3) which gives a peak at m/z 573.1689. During our attempts to isolate or characterize the intermediate A, it was realized that this species is stable only in presence of higher equivalents of base. An NMR tube experiment in dmso-d6 containing 1a with two equivalents of KOH shows only ∼10% of a new species in addition to the signals of the starting complex (See SI, Fig. S30). However, we are able to get convincing HRMS data for the in situ generated species A under catalytic condition but without nitrile substrate (see SI, Fig. S31). Further, an intermediate B, which appears in LCMS at m/z 676.2123, is formed via dissociation of a hemilabile pyridine of the bidentate ligand followed by coordination of benzonitrile. The nucleophilic attack of hydroxide at the electrophilic centre of benzonitrile generates intermediate C with an iminolate ligand. Further, rearrangement of the iminolate to amido and coordination of a water molecule gives intermediate D, which undergoes protonolysis to give the final amide product and regenerates the active catalyst A. Metal-hydroxy intermediates, similar to B and C, have been previously reported for the hydration of nitriles using other metal complexes [40,68,81] which follow a similar mechanism. 2.6 Recyclability experiment The recovery of the homogeneous catalysts from the reaction mixture has several restrictions, despite their various advantages. Due to good solubility of ruthenium catalysts in water, we are unable to recover the catalyst from the reaction mixture and reuse it for further catalytic reactions. However, we were able to recover the product of the catalysis using crystallisation and reused the remaining reaction mixture for few more cycles of catalytic reactions. We employed 4-Methylbenzonitrile (4c) as a model substrate to get 4-Methylbenzamide (5c), under similar reaction conditions as in Table 2. The aqueous solution containing 1a was reused five successive times, with a loss of catalytic activity after the second cycle (Fig. 6 ). After each catalytic cycle, the reaction mixture was cooled at 4°C in a refrigerator for 12 hours to get the crystals of the 4-Methylbenzamide (5c) and further reused the aqueous solution containing 1a in the next hydration reaction. 3 Conclusion In summary, a series of new electron-rich, phosphine-free complexes [Ru(CNC i- Pr)(CNMe)I]PF6 (1a), [Ru(CNC i- Pr)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (1b), [Ru(CNCCy)(CNMe)I]PF6 (2a), [Ru(CNCCy)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (2b), [Ru(CNC t -Bu)(CNMe)I]PF6 (3a), and [Ru(CNC t -Bu)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (3b) have been synthesized and characterized. These complexes feature multiple N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands, with CNC (2,6-bis(alkylimidazol-2-ylidene)-pyridine) and CN (2-(3-alkylimidazol-2-ylidene)-pyridine) as key ligands. The spectroscopic characterization of all complexes was performed using multinuclear NMR and high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) and the molecular structures of [Ru(CNC i- Pr)(CNMe)I]PF6 (1a) and [Ru(CNCCy)(CNMe)I]PF6 (2a) have been confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction technique. The investigation of the catalytic activity of these ruthenium(II) complexes revealed their high reactivity in the hydration of nitriles in an aqueous medium under mild reaction conditions. Particularly, complex [Ru(CNC i- Pr)(CNMe)I]PF6 (1a) exhibited best reactivity among all the complexes. The mechanistic investigation shed light on the catalytic pathway initiated by a [Ru-OH] species, where the pyridine bidentate ligand demonstrated hemilability, facilitating the binding of the nitrile substrate to the metal center. This catalysis was reported in mild reaction conditions i.e., low catalyst loading, low base loading, lower temperature, and less reaction time in an aqueous medium. The broad applicability of these ruthenium(II) complexes as catalysts for nitrile hydration was demonstrated by the successful conversion of a wide variety of nitriles, including electron-releasing, electron-withdrawing, and heterocyclic nitriles, into the corresponding amides with high reactivity and good yields. The present study contributes to the advancement of mild nitrile hydration as an efficient, versatile, and sustainable approach for amide synthesis. Furthermore, the successful conversion of diverse nitriles highlights the potential of these catalysts for the synthesis of valuable amide derivatives in various chemical and pharmaceutical applications. 4 Experimental section 4.1 General considerations All reactions were carried out under an inert atmosphere using the standard Schlenk line techniques. Solvents were purchased from S. D. Fine-Chem Limited and purified by distillation under an inert atmosphere. [Ru(CNMe)(H2O)Cl3] and [Ru(CN i -Pr)(H2O)Cl3] precursors were prepared by following a reported procedure from our research group using RuCl3·3H2O [74]. RuCl3·3H2O was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Deuterated acetone (Acetone-d6), deuterated dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO-d6), and deuterated chloroform (CDCl3) were purchased either from EURISOtop or Sigma-Aldrich. NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance (III) spectrometer and Bruker Avance NEO spectrometer operating at 400 and 500 MHz for 1H, 162 and 202 MHz for 31P, and 101 and 126 MHz for 13C NMR, respectively. NMR chemical shifts are reported in ppm and referenced to the solvent peaks for 1H (acetone-d6, δ 2.05, CDCl3 δ 7.26 and DMSO-d6 δ 2.50 ppm) and 13C (natural abundance of 13C in acetone-d6, δ 29.84 and δ 206.26, CDCl3 δ 77.16 and DMSO-d6 δ 39.52 ppm). 31P NMR chemical shifts are referenced to an external 85% H3PO4 standard as 0 ppm. Multiplicities are given as s (singlet), d (doublet), t (triplet), and m (multiplet), and the coupling constants J are given in hertz. The mass chromatograms were recorded on Bruker-Daltonics-MicroTOF-QII mass spectrometer in HPLC grade methanol (catalytic samples) and acetonitrile (metal complexes). Elemental analysis was carried out on a Thermo Fischer Scientific FLASH 2000 (formerly the Flash EA1112) CHNS-O elemental analyser. GC Samples were analysed in Shimadzu QP2010 Ultra, without an internal standard in HPLC grade methanol. 4.2 Preparation of ligand precursor The preparation of different alkyl-substituted pincer ligands (CNC i -Pr·2HBr = 2,6-bis[3-(isopropyl)imidazolium]pyridine dibromide and CNCCy·2HBr = 2,6-bis[3-(cyclohexyl)imidazolium]pyridine dibromide and CNC t -Bu·2HBr = 2,6-bis[3-(tert-butyl)imidazolium]pyridine dibromide) was based on the previously reported method [75,76]. 4.3 General procedure for the synthesis of metal complexes An oven-dried Schlenk tube with a magnetic stirring bar was charged with ligand precursor (1 equiv.), ruthenium precursor (1 equiv.), and NaI (0.149 g, 1mmol) in ethylene glycol (10 ml), the resulted mixture was refluxed under N2 atmosphere for 4 h. After the reaction was completed, cooled to room temperature and added an aqueous solution of KPF6 (0.184 g, 1 mmol, 10 ml water), then stirred for 2 min at room temperature. A desired complex was precipitated out, filtered the precipitate, washed with H2O, and dried under vacuum. 4.4 Synthesis of complex (1a) [Ru(CNC i-Pr)(CNMe)I]PF6 Complex (1a) was prepared by the general procedure of complex synthesis, from 2,6-bis[3-(isopropyl)imidazolium]pyridine dibromide (0.114 g, 0.25 mmol) and [Ru(CNMe)(H2O)Cl3] (0.096 g, 0.25 mmol) to give the desired complex as a dark yellow solid. The data collection was evaluated with the help of CrysAlisPro CCD software. Using Olex2 [82], the structure was solved with the SHELXT [83] structure solution program using Intrinsic Phasing and refined with the SHELXL [84] refinement package using least squares minimization. Final refinement included atomic positions for all the atoms, anisotropic thermal parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms, and isotropic thermal parameters for all the hydrogen atoms. For complex 1a, a solvent mask was calculated and 68 electrons were found in a volume of 474 Å3 in one void per unit cell. This is consistent with the presence of one methanol solvent molecule per asymmetric unit which accounts for 72 electrons per unit cell. ORTEP views of the complexes were obtained using the ORTEP-3 program [85]. Details of the structural parameters and final refinements for the complexes 1a and 2a are given in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and bond angles for both the complexes are given in Table S2. CCDC numbers 2263541 and 2263542 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for complexes 1a and 2a, respectively. 4.11 General procedure for catalyst optimization of the hydration of benzonitrile In a Schlenk tube, benzonitrile (0.103 ml, 1 mmol), ruthenium catalysts (0.5-1 mol%, 0.005-0.01 mmol) and different bases (10-20 mol%, 0.1-0.2 mmol)) were dissolved in H2O (5 ml) under an open-air condition. The reaction mixture was quickly heated to reflux by lowering into a preheated oil bath at different temperature and time. The conversion of the benzamide product was determined by the relative peak area of the reactant and the product in GC without an internal standard. 4.12 General procedure for substrate scope for hydration of nitriles In a Schlenk tube, Nitriles (1 mmol), catalyst 1a (0.008 g, 0.01 mmol) and NaOH (0.008 g, 0.2 mmol) were dissolved in H2O (5 ml) under an open-air condition. The reaction mixture was heated at 60 °C for 6 h. After completion of the reaction the reaction mixture was cooled at 4 °C to get the crystals of the amides in most of the cases and some of them were purified by silica gel column chromatography using hexane and ethyl acetate as an eluent. NMR data for the amide products matched with the reported values. 4.13 Experimental details for mass analysis of the hydration of benzonitrile In a Schlenk tube, catalyst 1a (0.008 g, 0.01 mmol) was added to a solution of benzonitrile (0.103 ml, 1 mmol) and NaOH (0.008 g, 0.2 mmol) in H2O under open-air condition. The resulting reaction mixture was heated at 60 °C, by lowering into a preheated oil bath and then samples were taken at 1 h and 3 h for LCMS analysis. 4.14 Identification of intermediate (A) [Ru(CNC i-Pr)(CNMe)OH]+ In an NMR tube, catalyst 1a (0.025 g, 0.03 mmol) and KOH (0.004 g, 0.06 mmol) were added in dmso-d6 under open air condition. The resulting reaction mixture stirring and heating gently for 30 minutes and then 1H NMR spectrum was recorded (See SI, Fig. S30). Further, LCMS analysis was done by adding catalyst 1a (0.025 g, 0.03 mmol) and NaOH (0.003 g, 0.06 mmol) in H2O in a Schlenk tube and the resulting reaction mixture was heated at 60 °C for 3 h under open-air condition (See SI, Fig. S31). coredata.dc:description: We report the synthesis, characterization, and catalytic activity of a series of electron-rich, phosphine-free complexes featuring multiple N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands, namely [Ru(CNC i- Pr)(CNMe)I]PF6 (1a), [Ru(CNC i- Pr)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (1b), [Ru(CNCCy)(CNMe)I]PF6 (2a), [Ru(CNCCy)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (2b), [Ru(CNC t -Bu)(CNMe)I]PF6 (3a), and [Ru(CNC t -Bu)(CN i- Pr)I]PF6 (3b) (where CNC = 2,6-bis(alkylimidazol-2-ylidene)-pyridine and CN = 2-(3-alkylimidazol-2-ylidene)-pyridine). Spectroscopic characterization using multinuclear NMR and high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) confirms the composition of all complexes. The molecular structures of 1a and 2a were further confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The catalytic activity of these ruthenium(II) complexes in the hydration of nitriles under mild reaction conditions and in the aqueous medium have been explored, with complex 1a exhibiting superior reactivity among the studied complexes. Mechanistic investigations revealed a catalytic pathway initiated by a [Ru-OH] species, facilitated by the hemilability of a pyridine ligand. The versatility of these ruthenium(II) complexes as catalysts for nitrile hydration has been demonstrated through successful conversions of a diverse range of nitriles, containing electron-releasing or electron-withdrawing groups, and heterocyclic nitriles into the corresponding amides with high reactivity and good to excellent yields.
coredata.dc:title: Cationic ruthenium(II)-CNC pincer complexes as phosphine-free catalysts for nitrile hydration to amides in aqueous medium
